etymologies: Middle English: the noun from Latin animal, based on Latin animalis ‘having breath’ from anima ‘breath’; the adjective via Old French from Latin animalis

definitions: a living organism that feeds on organic matter, typically having specialized sense organs and nervous system and able to respond rapidly to stimuli

examples.text: wild animals adapt badly to a caged life
humans are the only animals who weep

notes.text: Animals are generally distinguished from plants by being unable to synthesize organic molecules from inorganic ones, so that they have to feed on plants or on other animals. They are typically able to move about, although this ability is sometimes restricted to a particular stage in the life cycle. The great majority of animals are invertebrates, of which there are some thirty phyla; the vertebrates constitute but a single subphylum. See also higher animals, lower animals

definitions: an animal as opposed to a human being

examples.text: are humans superior to animals, or just different?

definitions: a mammal, as opposed to a bird, reptile, fish, or insect

examples.text: the snowfall seemed to have chased all birds, animals, and men indoors

definitions: a person without human attributes or civilizing influences, especially someone who is very cruel, violent, or repulsive

examples.text: those men have to be animals—what they did to that boy was savage

definitions: a particular type of person or thing

examples.text: the government that followed the election was a very different animal

definitions: relating to or characteristic of animals

examples.text: a wide range of animal species

definitions: of animals as distinct from plants

examples.text: tissues of animal and vegetable protein

definitions: characteristic of the physical and instinctive needs of animals; of the flesh rather than the spirit or intellect

examples.text: a crude surrender to animal lust
